column4: Hello, I am considering on transitioning my kernel from i386 to i686 due to numerous claims that it improves performance. But first of all, I just wanted to know will it break anything? Do I have anything to lose by transitioning to i686?
I have both 386 and 686 kernels in my grub menu, 686 is a bit faster but has some odd things like.. will not power off, just gets to a will shut down prompt
How did you mount it?
sudo mount /dev/hda1
Can you post your fstab to the pastebin and not into the channel
http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org/24260
Your windows is on a fat and not ntfs?
Is it a ntfs that was converted to fat?
Does your windows boot ok?
Okay, I tried booting into Windows. Works fine. Here's a screenshot of what the drive icon looks like. http://img245.imageshack.us/img245/1354/screenshotgn7.png
Sorry guys had to answer the door....
What does windows show as the name of the windows partition.. ANy funny characters there?
Screenshot: http://img245.imageshack.us/img245/1354/screenshotgn7.png
I saw that but what is the name as windows sees it.. and can you read it in linux ok or not?
I must ask... Have you run scripts like Automatix, (NOT recommending that you do.) to install anything?
Yes, I can see the files in Linux. Is Windows supposed to show another name than the drive letter for it's partition (other than C:\ in my case)?
Nope. I just installed Ubuntu a few minutes ago.
Windows explorer usually shows a name as well
It says "Local Disk".
An odd character in the Windows name might account for the funny name you see.
Hmm. Hold on a second.
NExt time you are in windows use windows explorer, right click the C drive and left click properties and see what the name is..
I checked the properties menu. No strange characters there.
I dont have an answer for the odd name, but at least you can get to your files.
